It took that long to admit? Mahmudullah's approach at chasing has always been slow. We lost the Asia Cup final to Pakistan and again almost lost the match against Pakistan this Asia Cup due to Mahmudullah's slow approach. Thanks to those no balls from Sami we won. Mahmudullah is a fine player. Though he always appeared to me as a top order and not a finisher. Coach thinks his best players should finish the match. Well, if your best players come in to bat after so many wickets fell, they will play defensive (under pressure) and there is no room for dot balls in T20s. Most teams play their best players up front. To me, the best players we have in stock for T20s are (in this order): Tamim, Anamul, Sabbir, Mahmudullah, Shakib, Mushfiq. Batting order is very important.

All of you are very emotional and have very short memory. I would like to point out few key points that you guys should keep in mind before commenting.
1. It does not matter what BD fans claim, they are obviously less mature than India.
2. BD started seeing success in home ground which is a good sign so the India was once tiger at home but cat at abroad. Even still they get beaten in Eng/Aus 4-0 or 5-0 in test.
3. Remember Ashween Tweeted before Oman VS BD game that if BD win than 1 country will be happy but if Oman win whole world will be happy, But no one condemn or criticized him.
4. It is just recently BD started seeing the success and therefore, their fans will be excited until they get used to it and as a matured fans people should consider this.
5. At the and of the day its a great news that we are going to have another (hopefully)strong country in cricket in Asia which will bring more excitement and good cricketers in cricket.
Thanks
</p>
</p>, <p>
All of you are very emotional and have very short memory. I would like to point out few key points that you guys should keep in mind before commenting.
1. It does not matter what BD fans claim, they are obviously less mature than India.
2. BD started seeing success in home ground which is a good sign so the India was once tiger at home but cat at abroad. Even still they get beaten in Eng/Aus 4-0 or 5-0 in test.
3. Remember Ashween Tweeted before Oman VS BD game that if BD win than 1 country will be happy but if Oman win whole world will be happy, But no one condemn or criticized him.
4. It is just recently BD started seeing the success and therefore, their fans will be excited until they get used to it and as a matured fans people should consider this.
5. At the and of the day its a great news that we are going to have another (hopefully)strong country in cricket in Asia which will bring more excitement and good cricketers in cricket.
Thanks

Some of you Indian fans who are going over the top with your Bangla-hate need to stop being so emotional and calm down. Let's just enjoy the drama of cricket and learn to respect people of all countries. This is cricket, not war. Stop being so childishly defensive about your team. And trying to defend your "honour" by denigrating the opposition is just in poor taste.

The biggest problem was batting order wasn't stable at all, its very hard for the batsmen to perform if their position is changing again and again. Another thing was we had a mentality that are weak in t20's...That's a psychological barrier that we could not defeat. Mithun's inclusion, Soumya's middle order position, not using an amazing keeper like Nurul was a downside from strategic perspective. Tamim-Imrul partnership has a good historic background, they enjoy themselves at any format of the game, we should use that in each and every format.
</p>

Sakib is good, his effectiveness is limited to right hand batsmen, specially when they try to attack him. We need a leg spinner or an offspinner to go with the quicks. BD bowling would be more threatening, if a spinner could go with Mustafiz, AlAmin and Taskin.

Bangladesh bowling has improved? Not true. BD's spin bowling has deteriorated significantly over the last year or so. They have one good medium fast bowler - Mustafizur - whose cutters are difficult to read for now, but it's only a matter of time before batsmen figure him out (like they did Ajanta Mendis). BD's batting is not even on par with Afghanistan. The only good thing they have going for them is good coaching staff.
</p>
</p>, <p>
Bangladesh bowling has improved? Not true. BD's spin bowling has deteriorated significantly over the last year or so. They have one good medium fast bowler - Mustafizur - whose cutters are difficult to read for now, but it's only a matter of time before batsmen figure him out (like they did Ajanta Mendis). BD's batting is not even on par with Afghanistan. The only good thing they have going for them is good coaching staff.

With Afghanistan winning against one of the best team of the tournament Bangladesh is the only team without a single win. Honestly I see good potential in Afghanistan due to their super athleticism and physique. But still I can't say they are better than WI.The point is the Bangla fans start cheering their side on just few home wins to the point they become careless and rude on established Asian sides. Whether Its Pakistan or Srilanka they are great sides and this is just a slump in form due to different factors. But they have produced world class cricketers and in few years they will be competing for the top slot again. Bangladesh and Afghanistan are up and coming sides and they have to prove a lot. Bangladesh was on the brink a few years back despite ICC investment and its very encouraging now that they are showing signs of improvement.

<p>
I feel sorry for the tigers. What a humiliating defeat in the hands of the same Kiwis who are just white- washed (called Bangla Wash) by declaring the intent a priori at home!! This huge defeat of Bangladesh by 75 runs in aT20 match surely does not tell us the story that Bangladesh is so novice compared to NZ. It appears that a few factors have caused this lowest total. First, the batters looked mentally and physically so exhausted, may be after these three defeats in a row, that their mind was not in the game but somewhere else. And it appeared to us that they were in a hurry to catch the plane to go home.  Second, we have been noticing that Bangladesh batting lately has become totally dependent on Tamim's or Shabbir's performance.  It is still a mystery to us why Tamim had to be so callous and catch a stomach flue staying in a five-star hotel. And he even had to miss the vital Australian meet.  Third, the tigers must improve their physical strength and fitness to stay in the business
</p>
</p>, <p>
I feel sorry for the tigers. What a humiliating defeat in the hands of the same Kiwis who are just white- washed (called Bangla Wash) by declaring the intent a priori at home!! This huge defeat of Bangladesh by 75 runs in aT20 match surely does not tell us the story that Bangladesh is so novice compared to NZ. It appears that a few factors have caused this lowest total. First, the batters looked mentally and physically so exhausted, may be after these three defeats in a row, that their mind was not in the game but somewhere else. And it appeared to us that they were in a hurry to catch the plane to go home.  Second, we have been noticing that Bangladesh batting lately has become totally dependent on Tamim's or Shabbir's performance.  It is still a mystery to us why Tamim had to be so callous and catch a stomach flue staying in a five-star hotel. And he even had to miss the vital Australian meet.  Third, the tigers must improve their physical strength and fitness to stay in the business

<p>
What BD needs to do as a team are the following: 1. Develop much higher standards of fitness and athleticism than you have now. That'll not only improve your fielding and running between the wickets, but also give you genuine confidence. 2. Develop mind power that enables you to take wise cool-headed decisions in the midst of chaos. You will then be able to do what's right for a situation, and not what your seething testosterone tempts you to do.  3. Cut down the violent aggro a bit. It looks amateurish and exposes your inadequacy and lack of self-belief. Good luck!
</p>

That'll not only improve your fielding and running between the wickets, but also give you genuine confidence. 2. Develop mind power that enables you to take wise cool-headed decisions in the midst of chaos. You will then be able to do what's right for a situation, and not what your seething testosterone tempts you to do.  3. Cut down the violent aggro a bit. It looks amateurish and exposes your inadequacy and lack of self-belief. Good luck!

<p>
It also get me thinking about the mythical spinner from sub continent.
No doubt there there have many great spinners but hasn't this tournament highlighted the obvious? That if the pitch supports spin then suddenly even modest ability is amplified? Harbhajan is being mentioned by fans now. Is it not true that this part of the world makes guys of average ability seem great? Anil Kumble. Don't get me wrong, i respect those guys alot but be honest.
Everyone in your power has been done to get the ball to do crazy things. If it's a muscle fight you get sand kicked in your face.  A muscular frame is required when bowling year in &amp; out to generate pace.
I seriously think Bangladesh need weight gain &amp; muscle strengthening programmes more than they do cricket training. They know the game. The fans love the game. They just need a little more lead in the pencil, so to speak.
</p>

The best thing about all this super 10 stage is, contrary to what we told by all the sub continent cricket (cough) experts, New Zealand have beaten Australia, India, Pakistan &amp; Bangladesh, WITHOUT Brendon McCullum, Trent Boult, Tim Southee, Matt Henry.  
We were told Martin Guptil would be shown as a hometrack bully who can't play on slow tracks. That's why the IPL wanted nothing to do with him.
We told New Zealand are imminently beatable. Yet they keep winning.
4 Games 4wins.  This New Zealand has not hit its straps yet. We have an amazing fielding unit that supports its bowlers.  Ish Sodhi &amp; Mitchel Santner have been stars.  MitchMac also class under pressure. I wish NZ we can play the next 2 games to its potential with the bat. So far it's been an outstanding team performance. Go the Blackcaps!

Hmm ... Interesting. This is the evolutions of the critics. Originally the question was " does BD deserve international status". Then it changed to " BD can only beat a team on a bad day". Then after some time the critics line was "can BD win consistently". It's then evolved to " ok they can play consistently but only on home Turf". Now some critics have come about with this new one .... " BD is an improving side but the BD fans are rude and ill mannered". Guess what critics... We'll take it! The super 10s have been enriched because of BD. The elegance of "the Fiz" the tragedy of Taskin, Tamims 100. The greatest T20 in history, the top 2 catches of the tournament from "the cat" soumoya. The BD train rolls on. Our fans are justified in our passion and of course will be offended by insulting TV personalites and commentators who sprinkle their prejudices to the baying public who in turn repeat those insults with greater fervour. Look to yourselves before criticising anybody else.
</p>

Hmm ... Interesting. This is the evolutions of the critics. Originally the question was " does BD deserve international status". Then it changed to " BD can only beat a team on a bad day". Then after some time the critics line was "can BD win consistently". It's then evolved to " ok they can play consistently but only on home Turf". Now some critics have come about with this new one .... " BD is an improving side but the BD fans are rude and ill mannered". Guess what critics... We'll take it! Some people are talking about the reactions of BD fans. Yes, some BD fans like to abuse other teams after a win. I really don't support these type of shameful activities. But there is a real fact, each &amp; every country has those type of fans. We didn't forget about the shameful activities from the Indian fans, Ind vs SL semifinal 1996 world cup. We know about Barmy Army (Eng). Cricket is a gentleman's game, we talk about sportsmanship, but Sledging is a common thing now a days in the cricket field. Pak &amp; Ind fans are well-known as  burner of dummies of the players, even they have attacked player's home many times in the past. But BD fans never did so. Why you people are bashing BD fans if they claim themselves as tiger? What's wrong with you if a BD fan says that we are gonna be world champion?  If I say BD is world champion, does that take any credit away from the real champions? Younger always deserves courage &amp; appreciation from the older, BD fans are really unfortunate in this case.

<p>
Not the skill alone can win you a T20 matches these days. Those who think well win the most. T20 is the game of deliveries. You need sessions after sessions to win a test match, phase to win an ODI and a single delivery can win you a T20. You have to trust your abilities every moment can bring you back in the match, One wicket and you are there to hope for another one. That's how Nz have been playing in this WC. If a batsman is hotting you out of the park, make him wait, break his tempo, keep him away from the strike for a few balls, even bowl a wide or two intentionally, if you are bowling well don't let the batsman think, let him not recover, have a go at him before he makes a plan.
</p>

Not the skill alone can win you a T20 matches these days. Those who think well win the most. T20 is the game of deliveries. You need sessions after sessions to win a test match, phase to win an ODI and a single delivery can win you a T20. You have to trust your abilities every moment can bring you back in the match, One wicket and you are there to hope for another one. That's how Nz have been playing in this WC. If a batsman is hotting you out of the park, make him wait, break his tempo, keep him away from the strike for a few balls, even bowl a wide or two intentionally, if you are bowling well don't let the batsman think, let him not recover, have a go at him before he makes a plan.

<p>
I really want to know how many "Man of the Match" awards are given to bowlers in the past 5 years across all formats of the game. I wonder if a bowler gets MoM at least 1 out of 10 games. A bowler takes 5-22 in a match and still a batsman who scored 40+ runs gets the MoM award. I understand that it is mostly the winning team that gets the MoM award. But I want to know to how difficult it is to score 40 runs in a 20 over match against taking 5 wickets in a limited 4 over spell. People might even say that it is a bowling friendly wicket. But how about all the batsmen friendly rules we had so far? To me a bowler taking 4 wickets in an ODI match is as good as batsman hitting a century. But it is the batsman who gets the MoM. Cricket is becoming more and more batsmen game and we all know that. But at least by definition MoM should be given to the top performer of the Match and not the top performer of the winning team. Otherwise legends list will have only be batsmen and no bowlers.
</p>
</p>, <p>
I really want to know how many "Man of the Match" awards are given to bowlers in the past 5 years across all formats of the game. I wonder if a bowler gets MoM at least 1 out of 10 games. A bowler takes 5-22 in a match and still a batsman who scored 40+ runs gets the MoM award. I understand that it is mostly the winning team that gets the MoM award. But I want to know to how difficult it is to score 40 runs in a 20 over match against taking 5 wickets in a limited 4 over spell. People might even say that it is a bowling friendly wicket. But how about all the batsmen friendly rules we had so far? To me a bowler taking 4 wickets in an ODI match is as good as batsman hitting a century. But it is the batsman who gets the MoM. Cricket is becoming more and more batsmen game and we all know that. But at least by definition MoM should be given to the top performer of the Match and not the top performer of the winning team. Otherwise legends list will have only be batsmen and no bowlers.

You may call me by any name but I firmly believe that this score befits NZ very well. And I am saying so in spite of their wins in recent WC or this competition. It has always been a team who had got most of the success in their backyards and whose reputation has been blown out of proportion always. I still remember their plight against the likes of Bedi or Chandra way back in 1975 or so. scoring the fatest ton or tripel hundered with maximum "aada balla" cross batted shots does not rate you better batter than SRT or Vivian Richards who could play with equal ease on both sides.

Bagladesh cricket team and fans as an Indian cricket fan firstly please accept my apology on my previous sarcastic comment. There is a bit animosity developing between both teams fans due to past few competitive matches we played and some of the nasty comments we exchanged between us during past month and half. My emotion took over me. Let us again be same good fans of real cricket than our own teams. You folks are truly developing into a good cricket team and that is good for cricket. Take Srilanaka on of our neighbors as example and develop cricket in your country and produce cricketers like Mehela, Jaisurya and Sangakara. Wish you all good luck for future and again please accept my sincere apology on my previous sarcastic comment and expect you also root for India and SL to go all the way to lift the T20 WC afterall we are all good neighbors.
</p>

</p>, <p>
<p>
Ban can do well in future, but for that to happen they should develop an embracing attitude than the current adversarial one. They have the talent, proven over last two years, but their mindset ignores opposition success and therefore can't accept things gracefully. The same goes for most Asian teams, our teams play well but some of our supporters don't know the difference between passion and emotion. Cricket, if played with passion will be enjoyable. Look at WI, NZ teams. They win and lose and remain loved by every cricket fraternity. Their fans are most cheerful even of opposition players. Indian fans have gone through the maturity phase, yet sometimes slip back into emotional state and abuse players for losses. That's understandable. But with better education and experience of life, fans will mature accordingly and appreciate good skills and performance than being headstrong and haughty over self performance- whether good or bad.
</p>
</p>, <p>
Ban can do well in future, but for that to happen they should develop an embracing attitude than the current adversarial one. They have the talent, proven over last two years, but their mindset ignores opposition success and therefore can't accept things gracefully. The same goes for most Asian teams, our teams play well but some of our supporters don't know the difference between passion and emotion. Cricket, if played with passion will be enjoyable. Look at WI, NZ teams. They win and lose and remain loved by every cricket fraternity. Their fans are most cheerful even of opposition players. Indian fans have gone through the maturity phase, yet sometimes slip back into emotional state and abuse players for losses. That's understandable. But with better education and experience of life, fans will mature accordingly and appreciate good skills and performance than being headstrong and haughty over self performance- whether good or bad.

<p>
BD's next challenge would be to succeed in tests. It would not be easy. Taskin was young and fast (he is suspended). The other quick bowler Rubel is injured. Sakib and the army of left arm spins would not it anymore. Mustafiz and AlAmin have wicket taking abilities. They would probably benefit a lot if there was an enforcer like Taskin on the other end. Bangladesh needs one more weapon. Tamim, Shabbir, MahmudUllah have matured a lot.  Sakib, Mushfique and Somya would be ok. Bangladesh's future depends if some of the younger players Mithun, Shadman or Liton can make it big.
</p>
</p>, <p>
BD's next challenge would be to succeed in tests. It would not be easy. Taskin was young and fast (he is suspended). The other quick bowler Rubel is injured. Sakib and the army of left arm spins would not it anymore. Mustafiz and AlAmin have wicket taking abilities. They would probably benefit a lot if there was an enforcer like Taskin on the other end. Bangladesh needs one more weapon. Tamim, Shabbir, MahmudUllah have matured a lot.  Sakib, Mushfique and Somya would be ok. Bangladesh's future depends if some of the younger players Mithun, Shadman or Liton can make it big.
</p>, <p>
<p>

Being a kiwi I reckon we know better than most how competitive they are so just makes no sense that some people keep calling them rubbish - NZ will definitely not underestimate BD in this last game, hope its a good one

This world cup was limited to 10 teams. ICC plans to do the same for the upcoming WCs as well. Under the current setup, it is very difficult for associates to come up. Kenya being a good example. I agree with you that BD still has some growing up to do. However, that day is not very far when BD will be a force to reckon with and will give all the big boys a run for their money. A win against BD won't be guaranteed anymore.

No reason you cannot finish off an a high with a win - NZ is eminently beatable.
</p>
</p>, <p>
At the risk of sounding like a broken record, one more time - drop Al-Amin (not a international class bowler ), drop Rahim ( not a T20 player ). Sahib looks promising, Shuvagato also. Focus on spin since you are missing your better seam bowlers. And good that you dropped Soumya down the order like I suggested. Best of luck. No reason you cannot finish off an a high with a win - NZ is eminently beatable.

<p>
well, it seems rest of the world is feeling uncomfortable by celebrations of bangladesh cricketers and emotional fans. But I find nothing to be so upset about it. I tell you the major reason for this emotion. Bangladesh were struggling a lot after getting test status. Huge amount of frustrations, unbearable criticism, agony of continuous failure grabbed the whole nation. It was a quite a tough period for a cricket crazy nation. From 2012 onward, Bangladesh cricket started to get some positive outcomes. although 2014 was again a tough year, but with the captaincy of Mashrafe Bangladesh cricket is currently passing the best period in international arena. All the frustrations, criticisms that were mounted over the nation are now reflecting with their winning celebrations &amp; feedback. But, I think now world has finally accepted the improvement of Bangladesh cricket over the years. So, no doubt that fans and cricketers will be more positive with attitude and celebration in upcoming years.
</p>
</p>, <p>
well, it seems rest of the world is feeling uncomfortable by celebrations of bangladesh cricketers and emotional fans. But I find nothing to be so upset about it. I tell you the major reason for this emotion. Bangladesh were struggling a lot after getting test status. Huge amount of frustrations, unbearable criticism, agony of continuous failure grabbed the whole nation. It was a quite a tough period for a cricket crazy nation. From 2012 onward, Bangladesh cricket started to get some positive outcomes. although 2014 was again a tough year, but with the captaincy of Mashrafe Bangladesh cricket is currently passing the best period in international arena. All the frustrations, criticisms that were mounted over the nation are now reflecting with their winning celebrations &amp; feedback. But, I think now world has finally accepted the improvement of Bangladesh cricket over the years. So, no doubt that fans and cricketers will be more positive with attitude and celebration in upcoming years.

<p>
Bangladesh being an extremely emotional side, will still find ways to hurt themselves with such mental heaviness. Being passionate is one thing, but being emotional is another. Being passionate will help praise opponents success and learn, whereas being emotional will only result in premature celebrations and over-the-top celebrations during rare wins (example: when Ban defeated Pak in recent Asia cup). When Pak thrashed Ban in Kolkata later, surely they wouldn't have celebrated madly in Lahore, Faisalabad and Karachi. Bangladesh players, with their resourceful talents, have to find a way to tune out their fans emotions and focus on the basics of the game, without wanting to aggrandize self achievements, which Mushfiqur and Mahmudullah will be forever guilty of.
</p>
</p>, <p>
Bangladesh being an extremely emotional side, will still find ways to hurt themselves with such mental heaviness. Being passionate is one thing, but being emotional is another. Being passionate will help praise opponents success and learn, whereas being emotional will only result in premature celebrations and over-the-top celebrations during rare wins (example: when Ban defeated Pak in recent Asia cup). When Pak thrashed Ban in Kolkata later, surely they wouldn't have celebrated madly in Lahore, Faisalabad and Karachi. Bangladesh players, with their resourceful talents, have to find a way to tune out their fans emotions and focus on the basics of the game, without wanting to aggrandize self achievements, which Mushfiqur and Mahmudullah will be forever guilty of.

Bangladesh have grown through the ranks without doubt, but somehow their attitude is amiss. They treat cricket as though every game is some sort of war upon which their lives are dependent on. On the other hand, Afghanistan has shown swifter progress, with cheerful attitude and gives every vibe of them loving the game. Cricket is entertainment and fans will love to see better attitude along with performance, example being West Indies. Bangladesh can remedy that attitude and certainly their game performances will improve as a result.

Bangladesh have grown through the ranks without doubt, but somehow their attitude is amiss. They treat cricket as though every game is some sort of war upon which their lives are dependent on. On the other hand, Afghanistan has shown swifter progress, with cheerful attitude and gives every vibe of them loving the game. Cricket is entertainment and fans will love to see better attitude along with performance, example being West Indies. Bangladesh can remedy that attitude and certainly their game performances will improve as a result.

<p>
Bangladesh cricket team has performed very well over the last one year. They gave fierce competition in the ICC World Cup 2015 and in the match against India 2 days ago they played very well and were on course to win the game, but were unlucky. I am certain they'll give NZ a good fight and can even upset them.
The thing that hurts the team the most are their fans. BD fans have a tendency to look at statistics that make their team look like a perpetually unlucky team. The fans neglect the effort that current and former players put in to get to the point they are at today. Giving out incorrect statistics in like the comment below
"BD is 7-1 up aganist NZ in last 4 years in limited overs. Good luck to Bdesh to make it 8-1." Will only bring the morale of the fans down.
</p>

NOTE: From Cricinfo statsguru, BAN vs NZ in limited overs for last 4 years is
ODIs: BAN(3):NZ(1)
T20Is: BAN(0):NZ(2)

<p>
Being on the field and playing the game is very different from watching the game on TV. But just by being a spectator, I thought there were enough mistakes in Dhoni's captaincy, with the exception of the last ball. But all that mattered to win this match was the last ball, so I would say in the big scheme of things, Dhoni was accurate. I thought Dhoni's captaincy against Pakistan was also fairly off, but India won that game fairly without a contest, so Dhoni was accurate with that one as well. I'm just hoping that all the inaccuracies that I feel just by watching the games on TV will start to disappear or I hope to get a chance in the Indian cricket team to convince myself that Dhoni is in fact accurate and that I just got it all wrong all along.
</p>

<p>
Dhoni did right by using Bumrah in the 17th and 19th over as despite a poor match,Bumrah is accurate at the death and is the 1st Indian speedster, who bowls yorkers with accuracy.A wayward Pandya might have conceded 10-12 runs leaving Bumrah almost nothing to defend in the last over.6 runs in the 19th over left Bangladesh with a substantial 11 to get in the final over and Pandya nearly conceded those,but for the harakiri committed by Rahim and Mahmudullah. Looking forward to a Pakistan win as that would deal a further blow to Australia's confidence after they somehow just managed to put it across Bangladesh.However,conditions in Mohali and Nagpur will be vastly different from what OZ faced in Bangalore. Hope the pitch India plays OZ in Nagpur on Sunday offers help to the spinners as that would make Ashwin and Jadeja all the more potent.Would love to see Bhajji/Negi play in place of Pandya as India badly needs the extra spinner with Nehra/Bumrah doing well in the pace department.

<p>
MSD's style of captaincy is similar to DL method &amp; therefore difficult for some to comprehend. MSD with his contributions as player &amp; captain has already leap frogged as the best ever captain in all forms of cricket in history of the game. Cricket is a multi-dimensional sport that involves batting, bowling, fielding etc. Rarely impact of fielding errors is analysed leading to erroneous conclusions about captaincy. IND missed opportunity of test series win in NZ in 2014 due to 4 dropped catches of premier NZ batsman that cost IND 350+ runs. BD bowled &amp; fielded well to restrict IND to 146 (a defendable total). IND would have won by a good margin had they not dropped 2 easy catches that cost 40 runs. As a result, the contest became closer. BD batted positively &amp; maintained left-right batting combination making use of part time spinners risky. As T20 games progress captain has to adapt to developing match situations. MSD's captaincy with bowling rotation was spot on &amp; Pandya deserved MOM.
</p>
</p>, <p>
MSD's style of captaincy is similar to DL method &amp; therefore difficult for some to comprehend. MSD with his contributions as player &amp; captain has already leap frogged as the best ever captain in all forms of cricket in history of the game. Cricket is a multi-dimensional sport that involves batting, bowling, fielding etc. Rarely impact of fielding errors is analysed leading to erroneous conclusions about captaincy. IND missed opportunity of test series win in NZ in 2014 due to 4 dropped catches of premier NZ batsman that cost IND 350+ runs. BD bowled &amp; fielded well to restrict IND to 146 (a defendable total). IND would have won by a good margin had they not dropped 2 easy catches that cost 40 runs. As a result, the contest became closer. BD batted positively &amp; maintained left-right batting combination making use of part time spinners risky. As T20 games progress captain has to adapt to developing match situations. MSD's captaincy with bowling rotation was spot on &amp; Pandya deserved MOM.
</p>, <p>
<p>
Dhoni's philosophy is sound but he is the creater of this chaos by his choice of players. In T20, economy in bowling is critical. Only Ashwin &amp; Jadeja have proven economy in bowling. Nehra is wayward as is Pandya. Bumrah can be very effective on his day but every bowler has an off day. So to support some of his expensive bowlers Dhoni needs one more reliable batsmen who can score against any bowling. Unfortunately Kohli, the sheet anchor of Indian batting, did not stay at one end as he always does. So it is obvious that India needed one more specialist bat who can stay at one end for a long partnership. Yuvraj playing just as a batsman is failing. Raina is also a huge failure! So one of them should be replaced with only other bat in the squad- Rahane. If Dhoni does not like him, let Bhaji/Negi replace one of the pace bowlers to provide economy &amp; restrict the opposition total! This Indian XI is unbalanced &amp; needs some changes to avoid "Chaos"!
</p>

So it is obvious that India needed one more specialist bat who can stay at one end for a long partnership. Yuvraj playing just as a batsman is failing. Raina is also a huge failure! <p>
Let this be written in gold, 'Dhoni is the best ODI and T20 captain India ever had and will ever have' at least in the near future. Less said the better about his test captaincy I find the documentaries more interesting than watching him captain a Test side.
Coming to his strength though in the limited over format his uncanny poise in face of tight situations is scary to the point you wonder if this man has any feelings at all. Then you have the jaw dropping decisions on field and somehow it is the right decision. I would not for the life of me have given the last over to Pandya but despite the onslaught we all know what the final outcome was, I would not be surprised if he gives Pandya another go in a similar situation next time. Dhoni himself used to the perfect words to describe himself in these situations 'managing chaos' of which I believe he is an expert. I hope IN win the title to give their captain the farewell he deserves.
</p>

JAYZUZ - If you have not seen any team fall over like that , you havent been watching cricket for too long. Steve waugh is credited till today for 1999 WC semis win or tie against SA even though SA was in grip of match all along. It was SA who couldnt get over the line. But Steve did his bit by getting his bowlers, fielders in place. Dhoni himself did it against SA in 2011 when SA lost 2 or 3 wickets losing by 1 run. Dhoni himself did it at the other end when he batted with Ishant sharma to score 40 odd runs and scoring 15 against SL in final over in Westindies couple of years ago. If BD choked - it was because Dhoni took his time to put his mind. If you watched yesterday's game, in the last couple of overs Dhoni was on his own planning and scheming, before Nehra stepped in . When  tough situations arrive, he knew how to get his bowlers Bumrah , Jadeja to deliver. Ashwin is a master at it. So,if Dhoni can take flak for all failures, why not take credit for victories.
</p>

The match was only stretched that long because of India's terrible catching. Had they taken all the chances they were offered (I count atleast 4 catches that were dropped), Bangladesh would have never got that close. It is about time, we thought of changes in our top order which is putting too much pressure on middle order. How about making Yuvi come early  instead of Raina. Raina only knows one way to play and he can get you quick runs lower down the order as well. I can also see Yuvi being under bowled even on spin friendly wickets which is hurting India in middle overs.
</p>
</p>, <p>

<p>
"Searching for a needle in the hay stalk" is an old saying. 
</p>
<p>
Dhoni &amp; his gang had that mini meeting before the final ball, precisely for that.
</p>
<p>
To find that needle of success in the hay stalk, swirling around in the middle of the ground. Stirred up by two mini, but conflicting  cyclonic storms of pressure from the neighbouring, but battling troops. Lead by two cunning commanders, of different ilk, with troops of different vintage, in terms of international experience.
</p>
<p>
In the last battle, two lieutenants of one commander, lost their heads going for glory.  His team got pinned down. The hang-man of the other, put the noose around the neck of the victim, as he was told. 
</p>
<p>
And finally, the latter commander &amp; his troop, who kept their nerves better, won. Found the needle of success. 
</p>
<p>
After the storm, such a calm. From pressure to pleasure. 
</p>
<p>
Meanwhile many of us lost a bit of our nails. If you were an Indian fan, that was worth the loss.
</p>
<p>
A nail biting game, at long last!
</p>

A target of 147 on a slow pitch meant a close contest. Dhoni made a tactical error to continue with Bumrah in the powerplay after he dropped a catch.  The clearly rattled Bumrah leaked 4 fours and this got Bangladesh going and stayed that way almost till the very end.  The counter balance was the bold gamble of Dhoni to bring on Ashwin in the 12th over to prize out Shakib.  From thereon India inched bit by bit to give themselves a shot.  Bumrah came back brilliantly with 2 pinpointed yorker filled overs with support from Nehra to give them just a bit of a better chance with 11 needed going into the last over.  The tables turned in the final over when Bangladesh blinked.  India stayed in the hunt and managed to pull of the heist. A hard fought prized out win.  Bangladesh despite losing clearly showed they could beat any of the sides on their day .  India needs to solve the top order puzzle to  stay in the hunt.  Rahane for Dhawan or Yuvraj will give them the stability they badly need .

Even though he only had hit one 6 playing just one ball... even that was important.  Keeping the momentum of run rate is more critical than saving a wicket in this high paced game. When I saw come to bat in that spot, I felt, in that that moment in time that he would just change the course of the game single-handedly all by himself. It didn't happen but it was a great gamble, in my opinion. I wonder if others felt that way as well. 2. Keeping Sarker lower down the order was a good move and and a good back-up reserve ammunision given his form not quite clicking or up to the mark. I think this new continuously changing conditions has a lot to do with it though... not his form.

You should never celebrate unless you complete the last hurdle, two fours on the trot and Mushfiqur Rahim was on the moon, he forgot the basics and   senseless in skewing the ball, Mahmudallah too followed him, rest is history. Overall Bangladesh played well, they are good team but they need to calm their emotions. Indian fielding was shoddy and was mainly responsible for bringing the match this close. India has now played three matches on turners, this sort of wicket seems to be following them where ever they go. They are still long away from mastering their skill to play on turning tracks. Hope the last match too does not turn out to be on a turner.

But one gets a feeling that the suspension of Sunny and Taskin was playing in their mind. In a way it looked like they were playing to avenge what has been unjustly timed suspension of their bowlers. In a pressure game emotions like anger and revenge can play havoc with your cold and calculated logic. Bangla boys will learn from this defeat. But no doubt this defeat will haunt them for long time. It will test all their resolve and mantle toughness to get out of this defeat.

<p>
Mustafizur Rahman was standing at the non striker end when the last ball was delivered: 19 meters from the stumps, with the bat and hand extension giving him a 1.5 meter advantage: 17.5 meters from the stumps.
When Pandya bowled, Mustafir had already left the crease and when the ball reached Dhoni's hands, he was already half way down the pitch: 10 metres.
Now it was a battle between Dhoni at 13 meters from the stumps (who had to start running) and Mustafir who was 10 meters away from the stumps with the added advantage of 2 meters (extended bat): 8 meters (who was already running in full throttle). Mustafir had a 5 meter advantage.
No other wicket keeper in the world would have tried to run all the way to the stumps considering the fresh fast legs of Mustafir. Some might have thrown the ball at the stumps. Dhoni tried to do the unthinkable. He tried to do the impossible. He took on.
Dhoni covered the 13 meter distance in 2 seconds (A start that Ussain Bolt would be proud of). History.
</p>
</p>, <p>
Mustafizur Rahman was standing at the non striker end when the last ball was delivered: 19 meters from the stumps, with the bat and hand extension giving him a 1.5 meter advantage: 17.5 meters from the stumps.
When Pandya bowled, Mustafir had already left the crease and when the ball reached Dhoni's hands, he was already half way down the pitch: 10 metres.
Now it was a battle between Dhoni at 13 meters from the stumps (who had to start running) and Mustafir who was 10 meters away from the stumps with the added advantage of 2 meters (extended bat): 8 meters (who was already running in full throttle). Mustafir had a 5 meter advantage.
No other wicket keeper in the world would have tried to run all the way to the stumps considering the fresh fast legs of Mustafir. Some might have thrown the ball at the stumps. Dhoni tried to do the unthinkable. He tried to do the impossible. He took on.
Dhoni covered the 13 meter distance in 2 seconds (A start that Ussain Bolt would be proud of). History.

<p>
Just like always, Dhoni is making up plans after the occurrence of an event.  The truth of the matter is all the deliveries in the last over were awful and yet the Bangladesh players couldn't win the game when and gave it on a platter to India. Why are people  praising Dhoni's captaincy? His Captaincy has been very poor in recent times. He was never a good Test Captain and he does not have great plans. Dhoni himself has created this great captain legacy to his name (not by coming up with or executing great plans on the field) by boasting about his own great plans is post match speeches. What he does is look back at what happened (if India wins) and say that his plan was to do exactly what happened and some people are naive enough to believe that. Most of his decisions in this match were very poor; most of all he should never have given the inexperienced Pandya the final over. It was not the bowling nor the captaincy that won the game for India, Bangla needed 2 singles, not 2 sixes!!!
</p>
</p>, <p>
Just like always, Dhoni is making up plans after the occurrence of an event.  The truth of the matter is all the deliveries in the last over were awful and yet the Bangladesh players couldn't win the game when and gave it on a platter to India. Why are people  praising Dhoni's captaincy? His Captaincy has been very poor in recent times. He was never a good Test Captain and he does not have great plans. Dhoni himself has created this great captain legacy to his name (not by coming up with or executing great plans on the field) by boasting about his own great plans is post match speeches. What he does is look back at what happened (if India wins) and say that his plan was to do exactly what happened and some people are naive enough to believe that. Most of his decisions in this match were very poor; most of all he should never have given the inexperienced Pandya the final over. It was not the bowling nor the captaincy that won the game for India, Bangla needed 2 singles, not 2 sixes!!!
</p>, <p>
<p>
India would have qualified even with a tie with Bangladesh (I think there is no super over for group matches) if they beat Australia. Then Aus/Pak would not qualify as they would be on 4 points max. Simple equation for India is to win the next match (in fact, next 3 matches to win T20 WC).
</p>

<p>
What India would want is Pakistan to beat Australia (or it to be a rain-induced abandonment) so that even if there is a rain induced abandonment in India vs Aus still India will qualify. If it doesn't rain then India has to beat Australia to qualify anyway (given India's bad net run-rate). And the best India can hope for is 2nd position in the table as NZ need to lose badly to Bangladesh and India to win massively against Australia (extremely unlikely both occurring together).
</p>

Dhoni's dash to the wicket off the last ball was incredible, given the situation and impending result. The reason BD team lost the match was due to their over confidence to knock-off in GRAND STYLE the 2 runs required in 3 balls. BAD execution plan by BD team.

<p>
Mustafizur Rahman was standing at the non striker end when the last ball was delivered: 19 meters from the stumps, with the bat and hand extension giving him a 1.5 meter advantage: 17.5 meters from the stumps.
When Pandya bowled, Mustafir had already left the crease and when the ball reached Dhoni's hands, he was already half way down the pitch: 10 metres.
Now it was a battle between Dhoni at 13 meters from the stumps (who had to start running) and Mustafir who was 10 meters away from the stumps with the added advantage of 2 meters (extended bat): 8 meters (who was already running in full throttle). Mustafir had a 5 meter advantage.
No other wicket keeper in the world would have tried to run all the way to the stumps considering the fresh fast legs of Mustafir. Some might have thrown the ball at the stumps. Dhoni tried to do the unthinkable. He tried to do the impossible. He took on.
Dhoni covered the 13 meter distance in 2 seconds (A start that Ussain Bolt would be proud of). History.
</p>
</p>, <p>
Mustafizur Rahman was standing at the non striker end when the last ball was delivered: 19 meters from the stumps, with the bat and hand extension giving him a 1.5 meter advantage: 17.5 meters from the stumps.
When Pandya bowled, Mustafir had already left the crease and when the ball reached Dhoni's hands, he was already half way down the pitch: 10 metres.
Now it was a battle between Dhoni at 13 meters from the stumps (who had to start running) and Mustafir who was 10 meters away from the stumps with the added advantage of 2 meters (extended bat): 8 meters (who was already running in full throttle). Mustafir had a 5 meter advantage.
No other wicket keeper in the world would have tried to run all the way to the stumps considering the fresh fast legs of Mustafir. Some might have thrown the ball at the stumps. Dhoni tried to do the unthinkable. He tried to do the impossible. He took on.
Dhoni covered the 13 meter distance in 2 seconds (A start that Ussain Bolt would be proud of). History.
</p>, <p>
<p>
Just like always, Dhoni is making up plans after the occurrence of an event.  The truth of the matter is all the deliveries in the last over were awful and yet the Bangladesh players couldn't win the game when and gave it on a platter to India. Why are people  praising Dhoni's captaincy? His Captaincy has been very poor in recent times. He was never a good Test Captain and he does not have great plans. Dhoni himself has created this great captain legacy to his name (not by coming up with or executing great plans on the field) by boasting about his own great plans is post match speeches. What he does is look back at what happened (if India wins) and say that his plan was to do exactly what happened and some people are naive enough to believe that. Most of his decisions in this match were very poor; most of all he should never have given the inexperienced Pandya the final over. It was not the bowling nor the captaincy that won the game for India, Bangla needed 2 singles, not 2 sixes!!!
</p>

This match reminds me of the Brisbane tie between Australia &amp; WI in 1960. Kudos to Young Pandya for keeping his cool in delivering the last ball as planned &amp; for MSD to pull off the heist with sprinting to break the wkt. I was amazed that Pandya was dealt the task of bowling the 20th over!India has been extremely lucky in all their matches so far to come back from losing position to win except vs. NZ. This match only proved once more that so far NZ is the only team which marched effortlessly to Win their matches. India has to win vs. the Aussies to keep their WC hopes alive. I have said this before- this Indian team needs at least one more specialist batsman @#4. They are relying on luck knowing this to be their need. So it is matter of luck running out on them or staying with them that kept India still in the hunt. Will MSD &amp; India make the change or pin their hopes on Luck &amp; Kohli!

<p>
Actually, Dhoni should have not left Pandya for the last over. He must have tried to squeeze an over or two from Yuvraj. He had an opportunity when they had Bang for 80 odd for 5, right after Ashwin took out Sakib. He could have asked Yuvraj to bowl an over then. It would have given him a cushion of an extra over from Nehra/Bumrah....but it is all in hindsight now. Dhoni has this habit of taking it deep and throwing the most inexperienced bowler into the deep end. Truth be told, Pandya bowled an awful last over which deserved to be trashed but Bang imploded spectacularly and Pandya is now a hero....strange are the ways of cricket.
</p>

@HAMMADFAYYAZ:- You are absoulely wrong. Out of the last 3 balls only one was a low full toss that was caught in deep. Low fulltoss are tough to hit with power for a six. One needs to time them for six.  But the batsman tried to slog that ball.  The ball that got Mustafiz was a good length ball that hurried on him and was not short enough to pull.  He played a bad shot.  The final ball is Pandyas strength, like Dhoni said short ball that is muscled and hit the deck hard.  See you might think these are easy balls but for that bowler (pandiya here) those balls were his best delieveries that he can bowl to cause some difficulties to bats man.  The last ball and the 4th ball were gem of the deliveries under pressure to win India the match.

South Africa teaches us, players should be selected on the basis on performance; not records and past history. MSDs captaincy was superb in this match. His glove-work has been the best.  Stumping Shabbir was of high class.  He did not go out of the crease to hit but that few seconds his foot went off and finding that perfect time to connect the stumps got us the wicket. He removed one of his gloves to throw on to the stumps even before Pandya bowled!  He could have thrown on to the stumps from 15 meters but his confidence in running up to the stumps secured that run out!  His prompt thinking on crunch situation.  This is what MSD a totally different leader.

Hansie cronje, Ranatunga etc.

what this man is upto. Fans of other countries (including my fella SL fans) should
just admire and enjoy such games, learn the life lesson of composure of players like 
Dhoni, instead of claiming 'luck' etc. 
</p>

mentored every bowler and also guided Dhoni all the way through and that is why 
Dhoni respects him so much.

</p>

Hello guys, I do not want to take any credit away from India. I have congerculate them from the botton of my heart for wining such a close match. However, i have looked into the scorecard of IND vs BAN (http://www.espncricinfo.com/icc-world-twenty20-2016/engine/match/951353.html) and i have found this from my analysis. Please correct me what i am doing wrong. BD total runs should be 146. Please look the calculation below:
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Bowling runs calculation : Nehra 29 + Bumrah 32 + Ashwin 20 + Jadeja 22 + Pandya 29 + Raina 9 = Total 141  + Extras 5 = Total 146  (should be)
</p>, <p>
<p>
Shabbir was not out. Even though it was clear that he was in the air(both his legs) when dhoni took off the bails, his position on ground is supposed to be the last point of contact of his body or gear with the ground. And his last point of contact was inside the crease where he jumped of his back leg. This theory of last point of contact with the ground is used in many games like Basketball, handball, soccer and even cricket(where many player complete a catch by tossing the ball in air before going out of boundary and coming back inside the boundary touching the ground and catching the ball). 
</p>
<p>
Consider a situation when a batsman is running/standing well inside the crease and he jumps in the air and someone take off the bails. That ofc is NOTOUT. 
</p>
<p>
Of all the cases where player is given out because of his bat or leg being in the air is because some part of his body is touching the ground outside the crease so he is deemed to be outside the crease.
</p>
</p>, <p>

This theory of last point of contact with the ground is used in many games like Basketball, handball, soccer and even cricket(where many player complete a catch by tossing the ball in air before going out of boundary and coming back inside the boundary touching the ground and catching the ball).

India won only due to "Divine Intervention" , looking back cannot find any reason why they won, agreed, Dhoni was fantastic but still it was Bangladesh's match to lose. India's batsmen need to step up, Aus vs Pak match, Aus were 60 for 3 and Steve Smith, Maxwell, and Watson accelerated the innings from the difficult position to 190+. Unfortunately, we have only Kohli who seems to be consistent. Last chance India, please do well. All the very best. Let the "Divine Intervention" continue... I still feel Harbajan will be difficult to handle for Aussies, they will probably handle Hardik easily, even though I love Hardik's lower order hitting.

<p>
well played team India. The next match is very important against Australia. As of now Top order except kohli has not shown good form. Dhawan and Rohit seem quite ordinary batsmen in three matches. So in the next match Rahane can be good replacement of Dhawan as Rahane is much better fielder than Dhawan. In middle order I think Yuvi should bat at no. 4 so that he can get more time in middle and Raina &amp; Pandya must be kept for situation when asking rate is high or to accelerate the run rate. Dhoni should keep himself as finishing role. Now come to bowling Team India should play one more spinner in place of pandaya according to pitch condition as It will give team more option if one spinner had a bad day. Summary is Rahane must be included in next match in place of Dhawan n one spinner can be added in playing XI in place of Pandaya If pitch condition allows.

<p>
This was what T20 is meant for. Nail biting finishes. And in last over it can happen. There are numerous examples from IPL. So, a match is not finished until it is finished. If BD had done it in an ODI, I would have called it that BD lost it. But, since it is a T20, I would say that India and in particular M S Dhoni won it. Why are people getting surprised here? That is a ROUTINE T20 STUFF. Great match though. It can never say whether BD is up there and improved, or India has declined. Its about handling the pressure, and play to the situation with quick thinking. India did that. Plain and simple. BD still need to do more to prove themselves.
</p>

Shabbir was not out. Even though it was clear that he was in the air(both his legs) when dhoni took off the bails, his position on ground is supposed to be the last point of contact of his body or gear with the ground. And his last point of contact was inside the crease where he jumped of his back leg. This theory of last point of contact with the ground is used in many games like Basketball, handball, soccer and even cricket(where many player complete a catch by tossing the ball in air before going out of boundary and coming back inside the boundary touching the ground and catching the ball). 
</p>
<p>
Consider a situation when a batsman is running/standing well inside the crease and he jumps in the air and someone take off the bails. That ofc is NOTOUT. 
</p>
<p>
Of all the cases where player is given out because of his bat or leg being in the air is because some part of his body is touching the ground outside the crease so he is deemed to be outside the crease.

This was what T20 is meant for. Nail biting finishes. And in last over it can happen. There are numerous examples from IPL. So, a match is not finished until it is finished. If BD had done it in an ODI, I would have called it that BD lost it. But, since it is a T20, I would say that India and in particular M S Dhoni won it. Why are people getting surprised here? That is a ROUTINE T20 STUFF. Great match though. It can never say whether BD is up there and improved, or India has declined. Its about handling the pressure, and play to the situation with quick thinking. India did that. Plain and simple. BD still need to do more to prove themselves.

Even after winning as many world cups. this guy is all calmness. You can get another Sachin/Akram/Lara/warne but can never get another Dhoni in cricket The way he said 'Out' after that last ball without too much emotion or spice shows what this man is upto. Fans of other countries (including my fella SL fans) should just admire and enjoy such games, learn the life lesson of composure of players like Dhoni, instead of claiming 'luck' etc.

<p>
Well played Bangladesh. They executed their plans well during bowling but didn't plan while chasing. It could have been an easy chase had they planned well. Rahim and Mahamudullah gifted their wickets. Immature batting by both of them. Anyway, they are improving in each match and will be a tough team to beat in the near future. India didn't bat well as Rohit and Raina gifted their wickets. Rohit's wicket was unnecessary as India had scored already 15 runs in that over. And raina was trying to hit each and every ball which didn't make any sense. Anyway, they played as a team and they were charged up while fielding. Good captaincy by MSD as he rotated his bowlers well and dragged the match till last over. And the last ball was an intelligent work by MSD. Only he can think something like that (run out). And credit to Pandya as well as he bowled on the off side so that batsman could not reach. Good Luck to India for the match against Australia.
</p>
</p>, <p>

Rahim and Mahamudullah gifted their wickets. Immature batting by both of them. Anyway, they are improving in each match and will be a tough team to beat in the near future. India didn't bat well as Rohit and Raina gifted their wickets. Rohit's wicket was unnecessary as India had scored already 15 runs in that over. And raina was trying to hit each and every ball which didn't make any sense. Anyway, they played as a team and they were charged up while fielding. Good captaincy by MSD as he rotated his bowlers well and dragged the match till last over. And the last ball was an intelligent work by MSD. Only he can think something like that (run out). And credit to Pandya as well as he bowled on the off side so that batsman could not reach. Good Luck to India for the match against Australia.
</p>, <p>

Dhoni confessed during the post match that he used the time left which is a negative tactics. Umpires should have intervened here. Anyway, BD proved that India are no more favorites to win the T20 world cup.

I must admit Bangladesh fans are enjoying fruits of hard work of theirown great players like the Pilot aka Khaled Mashud...Sujon aka Khaled Mahmud...Sumon aka Habibul Basher.Mohammed Rafique...Mohammed Ashraful etc. They always kept you guys in loop in this dominating game of riches and poor. It's time for you to pay them back with more wins and appreciation from opponents. I came across this context by father of U19 cricketer Sarfaraz Khan "On start of any cricketing career,  there will two bags. One bag full of luck and one full bag empty of  experience. As days pass by the bag of luck runs out that is where you have to look to fill the bag of experience".I only wish Bangladesh don't fade out like other ONCE A CHALLENGING TEAM...Remember heroics of Zimbabwe, Kenya? And you see where they are now.It's time for Bangladesh fans to step up and respect opposite teams and step up to gentlemen game. Learn from rise of Sri Lanka. Please don't spread hate. Spread Love. Enjoy the Game :)

If BD wants to earn the seat in top cricketing nations, they need to perform consistently. And Consistency is the main problem. Every now and then BD sparkles with superlative performance against top countries. However, more often than not BD fails miserably and predictably. Pakistan has been poor recently and hence the India vs Pak matches do not bring the same passion anymore. If BD steps up and replaces Pak, many Indian fans would love to have Ind vs BD rivalry. Hats Off to the BD fans who are very passionate about their team.

<p>
BD fans can claim that their team has truly arrived when it actually BEATS someone. In the WC, BD has lost 3 out of 3 games. The defeat against Pakistan was a huge one. And the same Pakistan team was soundly beaten by India. Agreed, that BD pushed India to the edge yesterday and were on course to winning but that wasn't only because good cricket by BD. It was largely due to bad cricket by India. Indian openers were slow, the middle order didn't click and the lower order didn't fire as much as it was needed. On top of that, India dropped 4 catches. If after all of these things, your team still cannot close out the game and win, then it hasn't arrived yet. It is definitely better than the BD team a few years ago; better than Zimbabwe and Kenya but NOT as good as Australia, NZ, India and SA. Still a long way to go.

<p>
People who are sating that this game proves that BANG are better than Pak are hypocrites. The logic that they are using is "if x team (BD) performs against z team (India) better than y team (Pak) performed against z team (india), then x team (BD) is better than y team (Pak)" This may be correct in Mathematics (If x+2=z and y+4=z, x&gt;y), but in cricket, it is very flawed. Simply change x team to be Pak, y team to be India, and z team to be BD. If these people are consistent with their logic, then they admit that Pak is better than India, as Pak beat BD better than India beat BD.
</p>

It wasn't as before where BAN was being talked down to. Yesterday was a nail biter but don't forget BAN v AUS was also very tense. The IND team, know they had a lucky escape, they know they were out bowled, they know how they were slowly letting down their countrymen. We all saw the pictures we all heard the silence. This wasn't PAK, WI, SAF, AUS or SL doing this it was 10th ranked BAN! Although BAN was disappointed. the celebration by IND and her fans is an acknowledgment that we have arrived.

The ODI series wins they had against, PAK, IND and SAF plus their performance in the 2015 ODI WC garnered a lot of respect coming into this T20 WC. Bangladesh is a good team, they should be given automatic qualification in icc tournaments but are still not good enough to compete against the likes of Aus, SA , Ind and NZ. Most of sabbir's runs yesterday were through edges. Shakib was the only one in control of the bowlers except the ball where he was dropped by ashwin. Tamim was living dangerously and Mushfiqur's boundaries were due to luck. The scoop he tried was actually an edge for four and Indian fielders were not at their best . Sarkar was lucky not to face ashwin before. They were trying too hard to win and that was their undoing. And Pandya's last 3 balls were ordinary deliveries. They would have won comfortably had they taken singles. Instead , they tried to emulate dhoni and went for big shots and threw away their wickets. For a change it was not kohli who made the difference between the two teams. And Dhoni's stumping was a masterclass. If we are to win against Australia rohit and dhawan have to put some runs on the board

About 11 runs were needed off the last over. First ball, they take a single. Now 10 off 5. They hit a four, 6 off 4. Felt like darn, we're knocked out of the WC 2016. A four again and two specialist batsmen on strike. 2 needed off 3. Almost got up to switch off the TV but then I get up and get a feeling that we have MSD and Co. who can still pull this off, even though we had 1% chance of winning it. So I stick to the TV and whoa, a short pitched delivery from Pandya and Mushfiqur gets on the back foot and slogs it over to mid-wicket for Shikhar Dhawan to pull off a lolly pop. A ray of hope emerges. Two off two. A full toss, for a fraction of second it seemed like into the stands but as soon as the camera progresses, we realize it's falling within the boundary and Jadeja grasps it as he always does. Now I'm like, oh god, yer gonna give us a heart attack here. Last ball, MS with his presence of mind keeps off his gloves, grabs the short ball that Hom missed and shatters the stumps!!!
</p>

BD could have easily upset India in their own backyard and eventually triggered an early exit for the host WCT20 2016. But the BD's had had other ideas. Some inexplicable madness in the last over robbed them of their glory who contrived to loose under pressure.    
</p>
<p>
Superstar's (Read Dhoni) magical calmness in crunch situations does the trick again. India are back in 2016 WCT20 big time. 
</p>

My XI for future matches: Rohit, Rahane, Kohli, Yuvraj, Dhoni, Raina, Pandya, Ashwin, Negi, Jadeja, Nehra, Bumrah

<p>
To all India haters and doubters. I am surprised that some say "India does not deserve to be in the semifinal or final". WHAT?? After winning the ASIA cup, India were favorites to win the cup. They lost to NZ by 47 runs. Agreed. But BD lost to Pak by 55 runs.  And India comprehensively beat Pak (with 6 wkts and 13 balls). India also beat BD. I agree it was a close match and India did not do too well. But it is just one match. Remember, BD had nothing to lose if they lost and India had everything at stake. The pressure on India was immense. In group 2, India is the BEST Asian team. Full stop!
</p>
<p>
That leaves Australia and India competing for the Semi Final position. Well, Australia also lost to NZ and huffed and puffed to win their match against BD. I would say it is a tough call between India and Aus and hopefully the match on Sunday will decide that. Until then, please rest your doubts on India. Remember, they beat Australia in their backyard 3-0 in T20 recently.
</p>

<p>
Wow what a finish, but you've got to say Bangladesh threw that away. Both teams certainly had their moments, especially in the field and with the ball, but with 2 needed from 3, the game was for Bangladesh to win, especially with the field still out. Thoroughly enjoyed that chase with the continued swings in momentum, what proper T20 is all about, as well as keeping your nerve. Bangladesh just didn't keep it, whereas the Indian bowlers, fielders and Dhoni did. While Bangladesh, like Afghanistan and in 2014 Holland, are playing good cricket but can't seem to pick up victories. India on the other hand are winning games despite not being at their best, which surely makes them a dangerous proposition. They are still my favourites to win, especially as many of these players know what it takes to win a major tournament.
</p>

<p>
Good God, whoever created Cricket? We had not one but two games of the most excruciatingly exciting variety since T20 was invented. At times I thought my heart might be overwhelmed! Of course the Bangladesh/Indian match was the superior game. The current England batting is a shameful affair, although that doesn't stop heaping praise on the trio of Ali, Willey and Jordan (in that order) and the way they brought their team back from the dead. Even then had flamboyant Shazad done his usual stuff even for 20 minutes England would have remained in the mortuary. Bad luck, Afghanistan, new kids on the block and welcome! Bangladesh had outsmarted India and deserved to win. Their bowling was to plan, as was their batting, until the final over from hell. Four to win, with four balls to go and two of their most senior batsmen at the wicket. But vanity overcame them, trying to finish with too much glory. Last ball's sprint by Dhoni to run out the batsman (rather than throw) saw his team home. Wow!
</p>
</p>, <p>
Good God, whoever created Cricket? We had not one but two games of the most excruciatingly exciting variety since T20 was invented. At times I thought my heart might be overwhelmed! Of course the Bangladesh/Indian match was the superior game. The current England batting is a shameful affair, although that doesn't stop heaping praise on the trio of Ali, Willey and Jordan (in that order) and the way they brought their team back from the dead. Even then had flamboyant Shazad done his usual stuff even for 20 minutes England would have remained in the mortuary. Bad luck, Afghanistan, new kids on the block and welcome! Bangladesh had outsmarted India and deserved to win. Their bowling was to plan, as was their batting, until the final over from hell. Four to win, with four balls to go and two of their most senior batsmen at the wicket. But vanity overcame them, trying to finish with too much glory. Last ball's sprint by Dhoni to run out the batsman (rather than throw) saw his team home. Wow!

4) Gets bad ball and Rahim gets out, ok but Mahmadullah gets strike (better than new batsman to take strike).
5) Gets full toss and gets out, ok fine but again decent batsman Hom comes on strike.
6) Bangladesh won the toss.
7) India dropped dollies. India never drop catches remember.
Want more luck? Bangladesh. Lets decide on the coin then. Dhoni loses toss 70% time or more.

<p>
I would say India has been utterly unlucky to get 3 straight worst pitches to play. Bengaluru pitch had never been so bad or a turner atleast. I hope Mohali will be a belter. That being said, BD played good cricket and Dhoni's brainwork did some trick as well.  Hope all the india haters are having a good time to comment unwanted things. There is no IFs and BUTs in cricket. This is where you need to show talent and not becoming a hero in 1 ball by slogging. Remember an IPL match where 2 runs was needed in last ball, Shane Watson just tapped in front of mid-off and scampered for 2 runs. Now that's called brains. BD has not come this close before and were not able to handle things. India have had more success than bitter taste in last ball deciders, the famous one being Miandad's six for a bitter one and Rajes Chahuhan/Hrishikesh Kanitkar's 6 against pakistan. BD has improved, but not riped yet to compete to the core. Tough luck for them yesterday. India has a good chance to move on......

MSD with his contributions as player &amp; captain has already leap frogged as the best ever captain in all forms of cricket in history of the game. MSD has also been innovative as wicket keeper creating run outs / stumpings with amazing regularity. The run outs of ABD/Miller in CWC 2015, 2 stumpings/ 1 run outs v BD etc. would have been virtually "not out" for other keepers. Ground fielding &amp; catching is not a bonus with MSD as captain. Rarely impact of fielding errors is analysed. IND would secured a comfortable win but for 2 dropped catches going to 2 weaker fielders costing IND 30/40 runs. There were no on field screams from the captain to the concerned fielders with a concern that any such move would have demoralised the players. No wonder then younger of the 2 bowled exceptional 17th &amp; 19th over. Pandya was MOM. IND has the best team in WC 2016 &amp; it is time for batters to manage power play &amp; middle overs effectively. If IND play to potential another world title is not far away.

<p>
I think as a captain Mortaza was far superior to Dhoni in this match. Giving single over spells to all bowlers not allowing indians to settle against any bowler's line length in the powerplay and promoting Mithun n himself up the order so  that they has their best batsmen playing the game in the final overs. Both these moves were smart and innovative. 
On the other hand dhoni captaincy was routine to say the least. Scoring 13 off 12 balls is below par. Shabbir stumping was pure luck as he took off the bails as fast as he could neither it was very quick nor intentionally delayed(or do dhoni supporters claim that he intentionally clipped the bails exactly at the instance shabbir jumped) and last ball runout was what you would expect of any international wc. How about the catch he dropped of soumaya sarkar off Bumrah. A lot of international WC ould have taken that.
And about the 2 balls before the last ball, I dont think Dhoni would claim that he had advised Pandya to ball full tosses!
</p>

This LUCKY WIN by India has got nothing to do with MS Dhoni calmness or any other factors that the Indian fans are crediting their team of. This was pathetic batting by Mahmudullah Riad and Mushfiqur Rahim. The deliveries that both batsmen got out from were just awful which could have been dispatched anywhere in the ground and on the floor. When Bangladesh needed 2 runs from 3 balls then the priority was for the batsmen to score a single and make it safe and then go for the winning shot. But our two batsmen wanted to be heroes and were seeing the big HEADLINES the day after. Funny how the last delivery was never checked for height or from the bowlers point of delivery mark due to being such a crucial moment.
</p>

He definitely have nerves of steel. I am a huge MS fan and could not have got a better chance to witness his class behind the stumps and captaincy. Apart from this, it was good to see Nehra encouraging two youngsters in crucial moments of the match. Definitely his experience came handy yesterday. As I said, Dhoni was at his best. His habit to back and instill confidence to it's team mates is just amazing. The way he backed Bumrah after his bad day at field was clearly visible in his last 2 overs. It was exceptional stuff from the young lad. Nehra too was  too good with his death overs. 2 stumpings from MS and that presence of mind in last ball by not throwing the it to stumps but by running and dislodging the stumps was extra ordinary stuff from our skipper. I am damn lucky to witness it all.

I don't know why Pandya is being singled out when he performed pretty decently,he was the only batsman who looked comfortable,he smacked 2 fours and a six in no time,he was the reason the run rate went up from below 6.5 to 7.5 and he did get out at the wrong time,but he did not throw his wicket,it was only due to the brilliance of Soumya Sarkar he had to walk back to the pavilion.I don't think any other fielder from Bangladesh would have pulled that catch and that did change the course of the match,if Pandya would have batted 2 more overs he would have sealed the match in the first innings itself.Anybody who is criticizing Pandya here either hasn't watched the match or has poor cricket sense.But what a fielder this Soumya Sarkar is,one against Pakistan and now this one against India,can't make out which one is better.Both the catches were exceptional,he has shown athletic brilliance very rarely seen in players from sub continent.

Two teams played like trying to lose and the better team lost. Much needed thriller for a world cup. There is no luck factor here. India put up a decent total but they let down in the field and Bangladesh returned India's gift in South African style. The last over is a lesson for both bowlers on how not to bowl and batsman on how not to bat. Man of Match should have been for Dhoni for his WK. His 2 stumping and the run out made the difference. High time India look at its batsmen and decide if a players 100 in one match is more worth than consistent scores in many matches. High time Bangladesh and its fan give their opposition the respect that it expects and earn it on the field by being humble as well. Thats why when India lost to NZ it did not feel that bad!

<p>
My man of the match award should go to Dhoni. Here is why.
1) Promoted Pandya above himself. Though it was a minor cameo from Pandya, it was indeed crucial at that time to get quick runs.
2) On the last ball of Indian innings digs out a perfect yorker and immediately takes off for 2 "lucky" runs, inspite of Ashwin shouting "NO" for the 2nd one.
3) Does two swift stumpings to get rid dangerous and settled batsmen  Tamim and Sabbir.
4)Brings in Ashwin at right times to get breakthroughs.(Shakib and Mithun)
5) With his pep talk inspires an off color Bumrah to bowl that excellent penultimate over.
6) After Mushfiqur's catch on 31rd ball of the last over, swaps Dhawan with Jadeja anticipating a running catch at midwicket. Which Jaddu did take of Mahmadullah.
7) Finally right before the last ball takes out his right glove, in anticipation of a bye to be taken and doest'nt throw but runs towards the wickets with the ball to run out Mustafizur.
"Cricinfo please make this a featured article."
</p>
</p>, <p>
My man of the match award should go to Dhoni. Here is why.
1) Promoted Pandya above himself. Though it was a minor cameo from Pandya, it was indeed crucial at that time to get quick runs.
2) On the last ball of Indian innings digs out a perfect yorker and immediately takes off for 2 "lucky" runs, inspite of Ashwin shouting "NO" for the 2nd one.
3) Does two swift stumpings to get rid dangerous and settled batsmen  Tamim and Sabbir.
4)Brings in Ashwin at right times to get breakthroughs.(Shakib and Mithun)
5) With his pep talk inspires an off color Bumrah to bowl that excellent penultimate over.
6) After Mushfiqur's catch on 31rd ball of the last over, swaps Dhawan with Jadeja anticipating a running catch at midwicket. Which Jaddu did take of Mahmadullah.
7) Finally right before the last ball takes out his right glove, in anticipation of a bye to be taken and doest'nt throw but runs towards the wickets with the ball to run out Mustafizur.
"Cricinfo please make this a featured article."
</p>, <p>

Furthermore, Aus DON'T need two straight wins. Due to India's dismal NRR, Aus can lose narrowly to Pakistan and beat India to qualify. I too wouldn't say 'sitting pretty', but India should not be confident making the semis either.

<p>
Those who say India is lucky - Remember that Australia was lucky to win 1999 WC when SA lost under similar circumstances. Luck or no luck, India did well to win from a situation where all was lost. For those who did not notice, Yuvraj saved 2 certain fours - 8 crucial runs. He plays from his heart always. Everyone has a bad day. Congrats - MSD for captaincy and the runout as if his life depended on it, Rohit and Dhawan for a decent start, Virat and Raina added useful runs and some catches, Bumrah, Nehra, Jadeja and Ashwin for some tight bowling. Pandya for the important runs and the last over that he bowled. Yuvi for the 8 runs he saved...Had he bowled a great yorker when BD needed 2 off 2 they could have still got a single by dropping the ball on the pitch. The full toss was as if there was divine intervention for India to win and Mahamadullah mistimed his shot. He held his nerve to bowl the last ball just wide enough out of the batsman's reach.Thats teamwork for you and it is notluck
</p>
